text: on Thursday for the first time in 11
days opposition supporters took to the
streets again in Tehran to protest the
election results Thursday is also the
10th anniversary of student
demonstrations in 1999 that were put
down violently looking back now at those
scenes from 1999 it's striking how
similar the images look to what we've
seen in the last several weeks and
around and in many ways what's at stake
is the same as well there's been a
struggle between relative reformers and
relative hardliners for power and
control inside Iran's political system
the demonstrations in 1999 were sparked
by the closing down of a reformist
newspaper associated with the then
president Mohamed hot to me in recent
weeks mr. hot to me has also supported
the opposition and called for the
election results to be overturned what
we've seen today in Iran is apparently a
relatively large number of smaller
demonstrations several hundreds or
perhaps a thousand people gathering and
dispersing the reason for this seems to
be that the security forces won't allow
large crowds to gather but one of the
results of that has been that there's
actually been quite a lot of video
footage for the first time in several
days of rallies in different parts of
the city they seem to be located
essentially close to Tehran University
where these student demonstrations in
1999 took place and were centered but
they spread out to streets around the
city and people gathered chanted
dispersed and then seemed to reform and
demonstrate further as they went on due
to the severe restrictions placed on
first hand recording in Iran by the
authorities we've again had to rely on
blogs Facebook pages information we've
gathered from Twitter and YouTube to try
to piece together a sense of what's
happening in Iran and in a sense that
protesters continue to cover the events
themselves it's quite striking that in
Iran despite all the restrictions by the
authorities despite a block on cell
phone usage SMS text messaging being
down
and restrictions on the internet that
the protesters and opposition supporters
still seem to be able to document their
own rallies and get this information out
to the world
[Music]
you
